resources.text: The java.util.stream.Stream interface introduced in Java 8 provides new ways to work with collections and other data sources.
resources.boxed: The stream operations rely on lambda expressions (and thus, on functional interfaces) to be compact. Make sure you understand these concepts before you jump into this chapter.
resources.text: The general process will be the following:
resources.list:
• Convert the collection into a stream.
  • Perform operations on the stream.
  • Get the result of the operations, or convert the stream back to a collection.
resources.text: We can get a stream of any collection by calling the stream method of the Collection interface. Take a look at this example, where I use a list (which implements Collection):
resources.code:
//create list
List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1,-1,3,2,4);
//get a stream of this list
Stream<Integer> numStream = numbers.stream();
resources.text: Note that the Stream interface is also generic, its type parameter must be the same as the type of the elements in the source.
resources.boxed: Arrays themselves can't be converted into streams directly, but you can use the Arrays utility class to first convert them into collections (like in the example above).
resources.text: To turn a stream into a collection, use the collect method. The parameter of this method will decide which type of collection the stream will be converted into.
resources.boxed: Luckily for us, many predefined collectors are available in the java.util.stream.Collectors utility class. During this course, I'll only use simple collectors like toList, but there are more advanced ways to collect a stream as well (grouping by, counting, etc...).
resources.text: Let's extend the previous example by converting the stream back to a list, and a set.
resources.code:
//create list
List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1,-1,3,2,4);
//get a stream of this list
Stream<Integer> numStream = numbers.stream();
//convert it back to a list (this is a new list!)
List<Integer> numbers2 = numStream.collect(Collectors.toList());
//convert it to a new set
Set<Integer> numSet = numStream.collect(Collectors.toSet());
resources.text: The resulting list and set will have the same elements as the original list, since we've performed no operations on the stream so far.

interactive.instruction: Convert the list into a stream, and then back to a list!

resources.text: With operations, we can modify the content of a stream, or get some property of it.
resources.boxed: In the following examples, I'll do the conversions and the operations in one statement, as that is how streams are most commonly used. I'll also don't convert the streams back to collections, as it won't be necessary.
resources.text: I'll be using this Set in each sample:
resources.code:
Set<String> languages = new HashSet<>();
languages.add("Java");
languages.add("C++");
languages.add("C");
languages.add("C#");
languages.add("JavaScript");
languages.add("Python");
languages.add("PHP");
languages.add("Kotlin");
//print all
System.out.println("Languages in the set: ");
languages.forEach(lang -> System.out.print(lang + ", "));
resources.text: The first operation is filtering. It allows us to select elements based on a condition. The condition is given by a Predicate functional interface, which I'll specify with a lambda.
This time I only wanted to print the filtered elements, and for that it wasn't even needed to convert the stream back to a collection.

interactive.instruction: Remove letters from the list that are not 'a' or 'c'!
interactive.data:
List<Character> letters = Arrays.asList('c','a','b','d','a');
letters = letters.stream()
         .___(letter -> letter == 'a' || letter == 'c')
         .collect(Collectors.___());

resources.text: We can also count the elements. This time I'm interested in how many language names start with 'Java'. This means filtering first, then counting:
resources.code:
long res = languages.stream()
         .filter(lang -> lang.startsWith("Java"))
         .count();
System.out.println("Starts with Java: " + res);
resources.text:
There was again no need for converting back, we just needed the long return value of count.

Next up is mapping. This allows change the data of the stream using a Function functional interface and the map method:
resources.code:
//Print how long each name is: map from String to int
languages.stream()
    .map(lang -> lang.length()) //or mapToInt
    .forEach(length -> System.out.print(length+", "));

interactive.instruction: Map each letter in the list to a string!
interactive.data:
List<Character> letters = Arrays.asList('c','a','b','d','a');
List<String> stringLetters = letters.___()
         .___(letter -> String.valueOf(___))
         .collect(Collectors.toList());

resources.text: It's also worth looking at the anyMatch function, which will check if there exists at least one element in the stream fulfilling a condition (Predicate).
resources.code:
//Let's see if Python is included or not
boolean includes = languages.stream()
         .anyMatch(lang -> lang.equals("Python"));
System.out.println("Python is in the set: " + includes);
resources.text: This function also has a pair, allMatch, which will only return true if all elements fulfill the condition.
The real power of stream operations becomes clear when you 'chain' them together For instance, we'd like to see <b>collect the length of names that begin with 'P' into a new list<b>.
resources.code:
List<Integer> lengths = languages.stream()
         .filter(lang -> lang.startsWith("P")) //filter to 'P' start
         .map(lang -> lang.length()) //map to the length
         .collect(Collectors.toList()); //collect to list
resources.text: There are of course many other stream operations which I did not illustrate here, please refer to the Stream's documentation to see all.
